intro: Plectritis macrocera var. collina, commonly known as the Sierra sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Scrophulariaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It produces yellowish to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting various pollinators. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
